paragraphs.context:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
AMS, pneumonia

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
 ___ w/ hx Alzheimer's disease, dementia, DM2, anemia, 
depression, osteoarthritis transfer from OSH w/ AMS and 
pneumonia. Patient noted to be more confused than usual and 
complaining of general malaise today at her ___ facility prior 
to being taken to ___ for evaluation. She was found there to 
have b/l pneumonia, hyperglycemia and hypernatremia. She was 
given zosyn prior to transfer to ___. Transfer to ___ d/t no 
ICU bed at ___. Patient was receiving zosyn but had not been 
given vancomycin on arrival. 

At the OSH, initial vitals were: ___ 99.1 90% on RA 20sk. 
 Initial labs were significnat for WBC 2.6, k+ 3.0, Na 162 
glucose 489.  She was give 1 liter of normal saline.  She was 
diagnosed with hypokalemia and a pneumonia and transferred to 
___ as there were no open ICU beds. She was given IV Zosyn 
3.375 grams, was ordered for 1 gm vancomycn, and given 12 units 
regular insulin and 1 L normal saline. 

In the ED, initial VS were: 99.2 130 ___ 94% 15L. She was 
given 1g Vanc, tylenol, and 1L NS for hypovolemia hypernatermia.
 
On arrival to the MICU,  VS T 98.1 HR 107 BP 148/120 RR 27 96% 
on face mask. Pt is responding to commands and speaking 
intermittently but unable to provide any history.
 
Past Medical History:
Alzheimer's 
Dementia w/ behavioral disturbances
Delusional Disorder
Hemiplegia ___ CVA
Peripheral vascular disease
Hypertension
Coronary Artery Disease
NIDDM
Anemia
Major Depression w/o psychosis
Osteoarthritis
Urinary Incontinence
Pernicious Anemia
Dysphagia

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Unknown
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAM:  
Vitals: T: 98.1 BP: 148/120 P: 107 R: 27 O2: 96% on facemask  
General: Awake, intermittently following commands, no acute 
distress, mumbling not always intelligible  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MM dry, oropharynx clear, EOMI, PERRL  
Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops  
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, rare rhonchi on left 
anteriorly, no wheezes, rales  
Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no organomegaly  
GU: foley with translucent urine and possibly sediment   
Ext: cool 1+ pulses lower ext, upper extremities 2+ pulses, no 
clubbing, cyanosis or edema  
Neuro: Left sided weakness in upper arm, right arm able to 
squeeze arm. 

 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS
___ 10:10PM BLOOD WBC-20.4* RBC-4.15* Hgb-11.6* Hct-37.1 
MCV-89 MCH-27.9 MCHC-31.2 RDW-14.9 Plt ___
___ 10:10PM BLOOD Neuts-91.4* Lymphs-5.9* Monos-2.4 Eos-0.1 
Baso-0.2
___ 10:10PM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 02:21AM BLOOD ___ PTT-21.1* ___
___ 10:10PM BLOOD Glucose-352* UreaN-33* Creat-0.7 Na-164* 
K-4.6 Cl-132* HCO3-19* AnGap-18
___ 02:21AM BLOOD ALT-24 AST-19 AlkPhos-103 TotBili-0.2
___ 02:21AM BLOOD Lipase-28
___ 02:21AM BLOOD Calcium-9.4 Phos-1.6* Mg-2.2
___ 12:39PM BLOOD Type-ART pO2-84* pCO2-32* pH-7.46* 
calTCO2-23 Base XS-0
___ 10:40PM BLOOD Glucose-340* Lactate-2.9* Na-166* K-3.2*
___ 10:50PM URINE  BLOOD-MOD NITRITE-POS PROTEIN-30 
GLUCOSE-1000 KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-5.5 
LEUK-MOD
___ 10:50PM URINE  RBC-71* WBC-19* BACTERIA-FEW YEAST-MANY 
EPI-4
___ 06:18AM   LACTATE-3.1*
___ 09:18AM   SODIUM-121* POTASSIUM-2.7* CHLORIDE-95* TOTAL 
CO2-15* ANION GAP-14

ECG ___: Baseline artifact. Sinus rhythm at upper limits of 
normal rate. Left axis deviation. Early R wave progression. Low 
precordial lead voltage. ST-T wave abnormalities. No previous 
tracing available for comparison. Clinical correlation is 
suggested.

CXR ___: 1. New right PICC terminates within the right 
brachiocephalic vein.  2. Progressed bibasilar pneumonia with 
small bilateral pleural effusions.

LABS on discharge: 
___ 07:05AM BLOOD WBC-8.6 RBC-2.99* Hgb-8.2* Hct-25.3* 
MCV-85 MCH-27.4 MCHC-32.4 RDW-16.1* Plt ___
___ 05:02AM BLOOD Glucose-143* UreaN-4* Creat-0.4 Na-140 
K-3.3 Cl-108 HCO3-25 AnGap-10
___ 05:02AM BLOOD WBC-9.9 RBC-2.96* Hgb-8.2* Hct-25.3* 
MCV-86 MCH-27.5 MCHC-32.2 RDW-15.9* Plt ___
___ 07:05AM BLOOD Glucose-112* UreaN-4* Creat-0.5 Na-139 
K-3.3 Cl-107 HCO3-26 AnGap-___ with PMH Alzheimer's dementia, diabetes, coming from OSH for 
altered mental status, leukocytosis, hypernatermia and 
hyperglycemia likely due to pneumonia.  She was initially 
admitted to the ICU and then transferred to the floor.

# Hypernatremia: She appeared to have hypovolemic hypernatremia 
based on clinical exam findings of dry mucous membranes, 
significant respiratory variation in IVC diameter, and IJ 
collapse with respiratory variation.  This is likely 
multifactorial in the setting of worsening mental status related 
to infection in combination with dementia. Pt was calculated to 
have a free water deficit of ~5L. Her hypernatremia was 
gradually corrected over the course of 2.5 days with ___ NS 
after volume resuscitation with LR.  Her sodium was monitored 
daily and remained within the normal range. Would continue to 
monitor weekly while at rehab and encourage liquid intake.

# HCAP: On presentation, pt had worsening mental status, 
leukocytosis, and CXR c/w possible left lower lobe PNA.  She had 
a new O2 requirement as well.  She was started on vanc, zosyn, 
and azythromycin. She completed an 8 day course on ___.  
PICC was removed prior to discharge.  Over the course of her 
stay in the ICU, her O2 requirement resolved. At discharge she 
was afebrile, oxygen saturation in high ___ on room air 
breathing comfortably, some improving rhonchi at bases. 

# Nutrition/Goals of Care: It was suspected that her subacute 
weight loss is due to her dementia. She was seen by speach and 
swallow who provided diet recommendations. Also recent 
malnutrition due to acute illess. The issue of inadequate 
nutrition in patients with progressive dementia was discussed 
with her son ___. We dicussed adding high calorie supplements 
to her diet and asssitance with feeding. He will consider using 
an appetite stimulant with her outpatient providers. We 
discussed that there is no evidence that tube feeding will 
improve quality or longevity of life, which he recognized saying 
that he had dealt with similar issues with his father's chronic 
progressive illness and ultimately passing. 
DIET: 
Regular; Diabetic/Consistent Carbohydrate Consistency: Pureed 
(dysphagia); Nectar prethickened liquids Supplement: Glucerna 
shake breakfast, lunch, dinner pills crushed in puree. 
Aspiration precautions, please provide assistance with feeding. 

# HTN: Pt was mildly hypotensive on arrival and required volume 
resuscitation; metoprolol was therefore held. These were later 
restarted.

# Depression: she was continued on her home dose of 20mg 
citalopram.

# H/o CVA: She was continued on her home simva 20 and ASA 81.

#Anemia: Patient hematocrit trended down during hospitalization 
to 25. Labs were consistent with anemia of chronic inflammation. 
Hematocrit remained stable at 25. 

Code status: Full code, although son ___ is HCP and 
reconsidering and would continue to address goals of care

TRANSITIONAL: 
-monitor electrolytes (potassium, sodium)
-monitor CBC for recovery of RBC count
-add high calorie supplements to meals, assistance with feedings
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. DuoNeb *NF* (ipratropium-albuterol) 0.5 mg-3 mg(2.5 mg 
base)/3 mL Inhalation q6hrs cough 
2. Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5 mg PO BID 
3. Guaifenesin ER 600 mg PO BID:PRN cough 
4. Guaifenesin-Dextromethorphan ___ mL PO Q6H:PRN cough 
5. Simvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. Levofloxacin 500 mg PO Q24H 
end date ___. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 
8. Glargine 14 Units Bedtime
9. Bisacodyl ___AILY:PRN constipation 
10. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
11. Dulcolax ___X/WEEK (MO,TH) 
___ and ___
 
12. Fleet Enema ___AILY:PRN constipation 
13. Senna 2 TAB PO HS 
14. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
15. Norco *NF* (HYDROcodone-acetaminophen) ___ mg Oral qHS 
16. Norco *NF* (HYDROcodone-acetaminophen) ___ mg Oral TID:PRN 
pain 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
2. Bisacodyl ___AILY:PRN constipation 
3. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Senna 2 TAB PO HS 
5. Simvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
7. Dulcolax ___X/WEEK (MO,TH) 
___ and ___
 
8. DuoNeb *NF* (ipratropium-albuterol) 0.5 mg-3 mg(2.5 mg 
base)/3 mL Inhalation q6hrs cough 
9. Fleet Enema ___AILY:PRN constipation 
10. Guaifenesin ER 600 mg PO BID:PRN cough 
11. Guaifenesin-Dextromethorphan ___ mL PO Q6H:PRN cough 
12. Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5 mg PO BID 
13. Norco *NF* (HYDROcodone-acetaminophen) ___ mg Oral TID:PRN 
pain 
14. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
15. Albuterol 0.083% Neb Soln 1 NEB IH Q6H:PRN sob/cough 
16. Ipratropium Bromide Neb 1 NEB IH Q6H:PRN cough/sob 
17. Glargine 10 Units Bedtime
Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis: 
Healthcare associated pneumonia 
Hypernatremia 
Acute metabolic encephalopathy 
 
Secondary Diagnosis: 
Alzheimer's dementia 
Hypertension 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with pneumonia, hypernatremia 
(high sodium level in your blood) and altered mental status.  
You were treated with antibiotics and your pneumonia improved.  
You were also given IV fluids and your sodium level returned to 
normal.  Your mental status also returned to normal.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qas.question: (Content extraction) Which sentences in the note describe the future treatment plan for the patient?

paragraphs.context:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
Breast cancer recurrence 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Wide excision chest wall breast cancer recurrence 
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms ___ is a ___ woman, who was
originally diagnosed with carcinoma of the right breast on
___, which presented as an extremely locally
advanced, large exophytic necrotic breast mass complicated by
bleeding and repeated episodes of cellulitis and infection
required repeating admissions to the hospital and IV 
antibiotics.
Ms. ___ declined surgery, but ultimately agreed
with a radical mastectomy for palliative reasons.  

She was interested in being able to attend church and be able to
spend more time with her family and friends, which she has been
able to do.  Prior to the procedure, she spent her
time homebound requiring dressing changes every two to two and a
half hours and persistently had a very foul-smelling odor.

At the time of the right modified radical mastectomy on ___,
she was found to have an invasive ductal carcinoma, 19 x 16 x
11.5 cm with direct invasion into the dermis and epidermis of 
the
skin with ulceration, grade 3 and deep margins negative, less
than 0.1 cm from the deep margin for invasive carcinoma.  She 
had
nine negative axillary lymph nodes.  The tumor was estrogen and
progesterone and HER-2/neu negative.

She did well until early ___ when she was noted to have
recurrent nodules on her chest wall. She was seen by her medical
oncologist, Dr. ___.  On ___, CT of the torso
demonstrated the chest wall recurrence as well as progression of
nodal disease and lung metastases. She was initially started on
capciabine, but with marked and rapid progression of her
disease,she was started on oral CMF. She presents for a 
palliative resection of the chest wall recurrences. 
 
Past Medical History:
1. Stage IV metastatic, triple negative, poorly differentiated 
invasive breast carcinoma 
2. Schizophrenia (patient denies this diagnosis, treated by Dr. 
___ at ___ in ___
3. Hypertension
4. Stage IIA colonic adenocarcinoma (underwent right colectimy 
___, CEA normal at the time of surgery)
5. History of high-grade SIL; patient declined follow-up
6. Polypoid endometrial lesion ___ patient declined 
follow-up
7. Hernia repair
8. hemorrhoids s/p resection 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No known history of breast or ovarian CA.
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: NAD alert and oriented, bilateral hand tremor
HEENT: non traumatic, non iceteric
CV: RRR, no m,r,g
Resp: CTABL
Abd: Soft non tender non distended
Ext: bilateral tremors in hand
Breast: incisions c/d/i. right JP drain with sero sang 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:25AM BLOOD WBC-2.7* RBC-2.66* Hgb-8.7* Hct-26.3* 
MCV-99* MCH-32.6* MCHC-32.9 RDW-17.4* Plt ___
___ 03:00PM BLOOD WBC-2.7*# RBC-3.11* Hgb-10.2* Hct-30.9* 
MCV-100* MCH-32.8* MCHC-33.0 RDW-18.2* Plt ___
___ 11:25AM BLOOD Glucose-136* UreaN-11 Creat-0.8 Na-130* 
K-4.1 Cl-94* HCO3-27 AnGap-13
___ 11:25AM BLOOD Calcium-8.4 Phos-2.5* Mg-1.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ presented to ___ holding at ___ on ___ 
for a resection of her right chest breast cancer recurrences. 
She tolerated the procedure well without complications (Please 
see operative note for further details). After a brief and 
uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was transferred to the 
floor for further post-operative management. 

Neuro: The patient's pain was initially controlled with standing 
tylenol and breakthrough IV morphine. On POD#1 she was 
transitioned to PO pain medications completely. She was 
restarted on her home psychiatric medications 
CV: no acute issues during this hospitalization. CBC was checked 
pre-operatively. She was restarted on home amlodipine on POD#1. 
Pulm:No acute issues this hopsitalization. 
GI:She was started on a regular diet on POD#1 which was 
tolerated. Post-operative nausea was not an issue. 
GU: The patient voided on POD#0 and otherwise had no issues. She 
was taking adequate PO liquids on POD#1 and her IV fluids were 
stopped. 
ID: She was afebrile throughout the visit. Her white blood cell 
count was borderline low but remained unchanged throughout the 
hospitalization. 
Heme: She received venodyne prophylaxis for DVT. 
Social: The patient was seen by palliative care while in house. 
She was also seen by a home hospice provider. She was discharged 
with follow up with both although she had not made a final 
decision on initiating hospice care. 

On ___, the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, 
she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, voiding, and 
ambulating independently. She will follow-up in the clinic in 
___ weeks. This information was communicated to the patient 
directly prior to discharge. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. Amlodipine 5 mg PO DAILY 
2. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 
3. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea 
4. Cyclophosphamide 25 mg PO DAILY 
5. RISperidone 3 mg PO HS 
6. Trihexyphenidyl 2 mg PO HS 
7. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amlodipine 5 mg PO DAILY 
2. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 
3. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
5. RISperidone 3 mg PO HS 
6. Trihexyphenidyl 2 mg PO HS 
7. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H 
8. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q6H:PRN breakthrough 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours Disp 
#*20 Tablet Refills:*0
9. Cyclophosphamide 25 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Breast cancer recurrence 

 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care: 
1. You are being discharged home with ___ services. Please keep 
your surgical incision and drain site covered with a clean dry 
gauze and occlusive dressing that should be changed daily.
2. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day. 
3. A written record of the daily output from your drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. Your drain will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount. 
4. No showering while drains are in place. No baths until 
instructed to do so by your surgeon.
5. You may wear a soft, non-restrictive camisole or surgical bra 
(No underwire bras). 

Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity until instructed by your surgeon. 
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered. 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4.Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking the 
prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 

Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 

Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 

DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS 
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.
 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

qas.question: Which sentences in the note describe the history treatment plan for the patient?

answers.text: The patient was discharged to home with follow up in the clinic in ___ weeks. She will follow-up in the clinic in  ___ weeks.

qas.question: (Text Summarization) Provide a brief summary of the future treatment plan for the patient?

answers.text: She will follow-up in the clinic in  ___ weeks.

qas.question: (Content extraction) Which sentences in the note describe the future treatment plan for the patient? (Text Classification)

paragraphs.context:
Name:  ___                    ___ No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Fatigue.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with 3VD, DM, Alzheimer's who presented to ___ clinic today 
with two days of fatigue, malaise, dizziness, somnolence, and 
decreased PO intake. He was found by his PCP to be hypotensive 
with SBP 66 and sent to the ED.  
.  
Per OMR, the patient arrived to ___ in a wheelchair accompanied 
by his wife. Per wife, patient has been complaining of fatigue 
but no other symptoms. He was nauseous in parking lot but did 
not vomit. No recent fever, chills, syncope, cough, CP, SOB, abd 
pain, dysuria, or diarrhea. No recent med changes but he does 
take atenolol. The patient's wife administers his medications 
and does not recall giving extra dose for any reason. Reports 
glycemic control has been normal.  
.  
In the ED, initial vs were: 97.4 70 78/53 16 98% RA. Clinically 
dry on exam. Labs notable for creatinine of 1.8, lipase of 146, 
HCT 33 (baseline 36). EKG - nsr, <1mm STE V1-v3: no sig change 
prior. Will add on troponin. CXR was unremarkable. U/A not done. 
Patient was given 2L IVF and his SBP has remained >110. VS on 
transfer: HR 69 BP ___ 100% on R. For access patient20g in 
right arm and 18 gauge in right EJ.  
.  
On the floor, the patient is pleasantly demented and eating 
dinner. He reports that he feels completely better after the IVF 
and again denies any CP, SOB, nausea, vomiting. He initially 
stated that he had an episode of diarrhea at some point and then 
states maybe he has been constipated.  
 
Past Medical History:
TYPE 2 DIABETES  
HYPERTENSION  
HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA  
DEMENTIA (likely multi-infarct)  
DEPRESSION  
ERECTILE DYSFUNCTION  
GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX  
BACK PAIN  
HEARING LOSS  
FALLS  
known CAD- 3VD, without intervention  
Chronic Renal Insufficency- ___ to DM2 and HTN  
benign distal esophageal stricture  
s/p left carotid stent  
s/p groin stent  
s/p left nephrectomy for benign kidney tumor  
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
His brother had a heart attack @ ___.  There is no family history 
of premature coronary artery disease or sudden death. 
 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission: 
General: Alert, no acute distress eating a sandwich  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM,  
Neck: supple,  
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally,  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm,  
Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
Skin: Well demarcated round hyperpigmented lesions on palms, no 
other rash.  
Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, dry skin over backs of 
hands and lower legs  
Neuro: CNs2-12 intact, A&O x1 (self), answers questions 
appropriately but promptly forgets conversation.  
. 
At discharge: 
gen: pleasant male in NAD  
HEENT: anicteric, MMM  
CV: RRR, no m/r/g  
Resp: CTAB, no w/r/c  
Abd: +BS, soft, NT, ND  
Ext: wwp, DP 2+, no ___ edema  
Neuro: oriented to self, knows his wife's name and number. not 
oriented to date, year, place. 
 
Pertinent Results:
Labs:
___ 04:50PM BLOOD WBC-4.2 RBC-3.93* Hgb-11.3* Hct-33.8* 
MCV-86 MCH-28.9 MCHC-33.5 RDW-12.1 Plt ___
___ 04:50PM BLOOD Neuts-60.3 ___ Monos-7.7 Eos-1.5 
Baso-0.3
___ 06:05AM BLOOD WBC-3.9* RBC-4.27* Hgb-12.5* Hct-37.5* 
MCV-88 MCH-29.2 MCHC-33.2 RDW-12.3 Plt ___
___ 04:50PM BLOOD ___ PTT-28.9 ___
___ 04:50PM BLOOD Glucose-248* UreaN-20 Creat-1.8* Na-137 
K-5.1 Cl-105 HCO3-25 AnGap-12
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Glucose-380* UreaN-20 Creat-1.5* Na-135 
K-5.1 Cl-101 HCO3-26 AnGap-13
___ 04:50PM BLOOD ALT-13 AST-21 AlkPhos-40 TotBili-0.2
___ 04:50PM BLOOD Lipase-146*
___ 04:50PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01
___ 06:05AM BLOOD CK-MB-3 cTropnT-<0.01
___ 06:05AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-110
___ 04:50PM BLOOD Calcium-9.2 Phos-2.5* Mg-1.4*
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Iron-56
___ 06:05AM BLOOD calTIBC-325 Ferritn-126 TRF-250
___ 06:05AM BLOOD TSH-1.6
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Cortsol-13.8
___ 05:10PM BLOOD Lactate-1.4

Micro:  
___ urine culture negative
___ blood culture negative
___ RPR negative  
.  
Imaging:  
___ CXR: The lungs are clear bilaterally with no areas of focal 
consolidation. Previously seen pleural plaque is again noted at 
the right lung base. There is no pleural effusion or 
pneumothorax. There is prominence of the ascending aorta which 
likely represents post-stenotic dilation from aortic stenosis. 
The aorta is also mildly tortuous but unchanged. Heart size is 
normal. Multiple clips are again noted in the left upper 
quadrant. IMPRESSION: No acute intrathoracic process.  

___ EKG: Sinus rhythm. Normal ECG. Compared to the previous 
tracing of ___ there is no significant change. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old male with multi-infarct dementia who presents with 
lethargy and hypotension found to have acute renal failure, all 
of which was responsive to IV hydration.  
.  
# Hypotension: Patient's only localizing symptom is nausea 
without vomiting, diarrhea, fever or leukocytosis so infection 
is unlikely. A normal random cortisol ruled out adrenal 
insufficiency.  Urine and blood cultures were negative.  Most 
likely etiology is poor PO intake in the setting of 
anti-hypertensives.  He was hypertensive during the remainder of 
his stay.  His isosorbide and lisinopril were initially held but 
restarted.  His atenolol was held until he sees his PCP in 
follow up.  
.  
# Poor PO intake: Patient reported nausea last night without 
abdominal pain. He is asymptomatic, and ate three full meals 
while admitted. Labs on admission revealed a mildly elevated 
lipase with normal LFT's and white count.  ACS was unlikely 
given 3 days of symptoms and troponin is <0.1.  Urine and blood 
cultures were negative.  Most likely secondary to hypoglycemia 
prior to eating. 
.  
# Acute on chronic renal failure: Creatinine elevated on 
admission to 1.8, downtrending after IVF overnight to 1.5. 
Baseline creatinine is 1.2. Likely prerenal due to poor PO 
intake over the past few days and his positive response to fluid 
challenge.  His atenolol was held accordingly.
.  
# Rash on Palms: Unclear from notes how long this has been 
present. Patient had a negative RPR in ___, and unlikely to 
have developed syphilis since then. RPR negative.  
.  
# Anemia: Hematocrit at baseline this morning.  Iron studies, 
B12 and folate were within normal limits.
.  
# CAD: Patient has known 3VD that is not able to be intervened 
on. Patient denies chest pain and cardiac enzymes negative x2.  
He was continued on plavix, aspirin, statin, isosorbide and his 
ACE.  His atenolol was held given ___.
.  
# Hypertension: He was hypertensive during admission as his 
atenolol was held in the setting of ___.  He was restarted on 
isosorbide and his ACE on the second day of admission.  He was 
advised to hold his atenolol until he saw his PCP.
.  
# Type 2 DM, on oral hypoglycemics:  His glipizide and metformin 
were held while admitted and he was covered with sliding scale 
insulin. 
.  
# Multi-infarct vs. Alzhemier's dementia:  Stable.  He was 
continued on his home dose Namenda and galantamine.  
.  
# GERD: His dose of Ranitidine was reduced given ARF during 
admission. 
.
# Depression: Mood appropriate. He was continued on citalopram.
 
Medications on Admission:
ATENOLOL - 50 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day  
CITALOPRAM - 20 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth each morning  
CLOPIDOGREL [PLAVIX] - 75 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth daily 
GALANTAMINE - 16 mg Cap,24 hr 1 Cap(s) by qAM  
GLIPIZIDE - 10 mg Tablet - 1 (One) Tablet(s) by mouth twice a 
day  
ISOSORBIDE MONONITRATE - 30 mg Tablet SR by mouth daily  
LISINOPRIL - 40 mg Tablet by mouth daily  
MEMANTINE [NAMENDA] 10 mg Tablet by mouth twice daily  
METFORMIN 1,000 mg Tablet by mouth twice a day (take with meals) 
 
NITROGLYCERIN - 0.4 mg Tablet SL every 5 minutes up to 3 times  
PIOGLITAZONE [ACTOS] 45 mg Tablet by mouth once a day  
QUETIAPINE [SEROQUEL] - 25 mg Tablet by mouth BID  
RANITIDINE HCL 150 mg Tablet by mouth once a day  
SIMVASTATIN - 40 mg Tablet by mouth once a day  
ACETAMINOPHEN - 500 mg Tablet - 2 Tablet(s) by mouth TID  
ASPIRIN - 81 mg Tablet, Chewable by mouth once a day  
 
Discharge Medications:
1. citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
2. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. galantamine 16 mg Cap,Ext Release Pellets 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Cap,Ext Release Pellets 24 hr PO once a day.  
4. glipizide 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.  
5. lisinopril 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
6. memantine 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.  
7. metformin 1,000 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day. 
 
8. isosorbide mononitrate 30 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO once a day.  
9. nitroglycerin 0.4 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) Tablet, 
Sublingual Sublingual PRN (as needed) as needed for chest pain: 
___ take up to three times.  
10. Actos 45 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
11. quetiapine 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times 
a day).  
12. ranitidine HCl 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
13. simvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
14. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day).  
15. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
16. petrolatum     Ointment Sig: One (1) Appl Topical TID (3 
times a day) as needed for dry skin.  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis: Hypotension 
Secondary diagnosis: Alzheimer's and vascular dementia 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of your during your stay here at 
___.

You were admitted for an episode of low blood pressure and 
fatigue, likely a result of decreased oral intake over the past 
few days.  This resolved with intravenous fluid hydration.  
Please continue to eat and drink well at home.  

A thyroid function test is pending at the time of discharge.  
Please follow up with this at your appointment with Dr. ___.

The following changes were made to your medication regimen:
HOLD atenolol until you see your PCP
 
___:
___

qas.question: (Text Summarization) Provide a brief summary of the history treatment plan for the patient?

answers.text: Patient was admitted for an episode of low blood pressure and fatigue, likely a result of decreased oral intake over the past few days. This resolved with intravenous fluid hydration. Changes were made to medication regimen including holding atenolol until seeing PCP.

qas.question: (Content extraction) Which sentences in the note describe the history treatment plan for the patient?

answers.text: He was continued on plavix, aspirin, statin, isosorbide and his  ACE.  His atenolol was held given ___.

He was hypertensive during admission as his  atenolol was held in the setting of ___.  He was restarted on  isosorbide and his ACE on the second day of admission.  He was  advised to hold his atenolol until he saw his PCP.
His glipizide and metformin  were held while admitted and he was covered with sliding scale  insulin.
He was  continued on his home dose Namenda and galantamine.
His dose of Ranitidine was reduced given ARF during  admission.
Mood appropriate. He was continued on citalopram.

qas.question: (Text Summarization) Provide a brief summary of the future treatment plan for the patient?

answers.text: The patient was admitted for an episode of low blood pressure and fatigue, which resolved with intravenous fluid hydration. The patient is advised to eat and drink well at home. The atenolol was held until the patient sees their PCP. The patient's other medications were continued or adjusted as needed, including citalopram, clopidogrel, galantamine, glipizide, lisinopril, memantine, metformin, isosorbide mononitrate, nitroglycerin, Actos, quetiapine, ranitidine HCl, simvastatin, acetaminophen, and aspirin. The patient's mental status is confused, always, and their level of consciousness is alert and interactive.

answers.text: Please continue to eat and drink well at home.
A thyroid function test is pending at the time of discharge.   Please follow up with this at your appointment with Dr. ___.
The following changes were made to your medication regimen HOLD atenolol until you see your PCP ___ ___

paragraphs.context:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Dilantin Kapseal / Zofran (as hydrochloride)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right hip pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ y/o F with PMHx CHF, Afib not on 
anticoagulation, severe advanced Alzheimer's dementia, 
osteoporosis, HTN, who presents from assisted living facility 
with R hip pain.

The patient has severe dementia, with short term memory loss so 
is unable to provide history. Much of the history is obtained 
from multiple family members in the room. She has multiple 
family members who live close by and are involved intimately in 
her care. They were called from the assisted living facility 
this morning when the patient was in ___ right hip pain. This 
occurred suddenly. No trauma. No reported falls. She was not 
complaining of other symptoms. She was brought to the ED. 

Discussing with the patient, she moved into the Assisted living 
facility in ___ in ___ given worsening of her 
dementia. She was in her USOH, bowling weekly and very social, 
until ___ when she developed acute SOB with ambulation 
prompting admission to ___ where she was noted 
to be in Afib. She had a week long hospital stay complicated by 
an ICU course for an allergic reaction to a medication (family 
thinks Zofran). Since returning from this hospitalization, she 
has not been back to baseline and has deteriorated. She has 
spent much of her time wheelchair bound given deconditioning. 
She has worsening memory function, now with severe short term 
memory loss. Decreased appetite and PO intake. She was recently 
seen in ___ clinic by Dr. ___ new diagnosis of CHF. She 
underwent an TTE at ___ yesterday ___ to evaluate her 
systolic function. 
 
In the ED, initial vitals were: 
98.7, 96, 122/48, 20, 96% RA. 

Exam was significant for: 
R hip TTP greater trochanter, neg straight leg raise. ___ 
pulses 2+
LLE 2+ edema, unknown duration
Labs were significant for : 
K 2.8 
Cr 0.8
CBC: 13.9/12.5/39.2/168
UA: WBC 22, moderate leuks, negative nitrites 

Studies: 
Lower extremity ultrasound: 1. Deep vein thrombosis of the left 
common femoral vein extending into at least the popliteal vein. 
Left calf veins were not clearly identified and possibly also 
occluded.
2. No DVT in the right lower extremity.

CXR
Bilateral pleural effusions, large on the right and small on the 
left. No definite focal consolidation identified, although 
evaluation is limited secondary to these effusions. 

She was given 80 mEq of K and 60mg Enoxaparin Sodium. 
  
Vitals on transfer were: 97.9, 79, 125/53, 18, 100% Nasal 
Cannula. 
 
On the floor, she is resting comfortably in bed. History is 
obtained as above with family members. She sleeps with 2 pillows 
at home and has DOE. She has not had a bowel movement in 2 days. 


Review of systems:  
(+) Per HPI  
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats. denies headache, sinus 
tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough. Denies 
nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No 
dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias.  

 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
Dementia
Osteoporosis
Irritable bowel syndrome
Macrocytosis of unclear etiology
Left ear hearing loss
Status post hysterectomy
Status post appendectomy
Status post ovarian cyst removal
Cataract surgery
Glaucoma
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Not relevant to the current admission.
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAM 
==============
Vital Signs: 98.3, 107/43, 72, 16, 99 2L NC  
General: AOx1, pleasant, smiling, at baseline per family members 
at bedside 
___: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, EOMI, PERRL, 
neck supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, soft ___ systolic 
murmur.   
Lungs: Moderate inspiratory effort, decreased breath sounds 
bilaterally at bases L>R. No wheezes, rales, rhonchi  
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no organomegaly, no rebound or guarding  
GU: No foley  
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, L>R lower extremity 
swelling with left leg erythematous and tender to palpation, 2+ 
pitting edema tender, right lower extremity with e/o chronic 
venous stasis changes, 1+ pitting edema non tender.  
Neuro: AOx1, strength ___ upper and lower exteremities, all 
facial movements in tact, sensation grossly in tact, gait 
deferred.  
 
DISCHARGE EXAM 
==============
Vitals: T:97.9, 144/59, 72, 20, 93 RA 

General: AOx1, pleasant, smiling, at baseline per family members 
at bedside 
___: Sclera anicteric, MMM  
CV: Irregularly irregular, normal S1 + S2, soft ___ systolic 
murmur.   
Lungs: Moderate inspiratory effort, decreased breath sounds 
bilateral bases 
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, L>R lower extremity 
swelling with left leg erythematous and minimal tender to 
palpation, 2+ pitting edema tender, right lower extremity with 
e/o chronic venous stasis changes, 1+ pitting edema non tender.  

Neuro: AOx1  

 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS
==============
___ 11:35AM URINE  RBC-2 WBC-22* BACTERIA-NONE YEAST-NONE 
EPI-<1 TRANS EPI-<1
___ 11:35AM URINE  BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-5.5 
LEUK-MOD
___ 12:00PM   PLT COUNT-168
___ 12:00PM   NEUTS-81.1* LYMPHS-10.8* MONOS-6.7 EOS-0.1* 
BASOS-0.2 IM ___ AbsNeut-11.29* AbsLymp-1.51 AbsMono-0.94* 
AbsEos-0.02* AbsBaso-0.03
___ 12:00PM   WBC-13.9* RBC-3.78* HGB-12.5 HCT-39.2 
MCV-104* MCH-33.1* MCHC-31.9* RDW-13.6 RDWSD-51.9*
___ 12:00PM   CALCIUM-7.8* PHOSPHATE-3.7 MAGNESIUM-1.6
___ 12:00PM   cTropnT-0.03* proBNP-8428*
___ 12:00PM   GLUCOSE-118* UREA N-26* CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-144 
POTASSIUM-2.8* CHLORIDE-95* TOTAL CO2-38* ANION GAP-14

STUDIES
=======

CXR 
Bilateral pleural effusions, large on the right and small on the 
left.  No 
definite focal consolidation identified, although evaluation is 
limited 
secondary to these effusions. 

Pelvis Xray 
There is no acute fracture or dislocation.  No focal lytic or 
sclerotic 
osseous lesion is seen.  There is no radiopaque foreign body.  
Vascular 
calcifications are noted.  The visualized bowel gas pattern is 
nonobstructive. 
  
IMPRESSION:  No acute fracture or dislocation. 

Lower extremity ultrasound 
1. Deep vein thrombosis of the left common femoral vein 
extending into at 
least the popliteal vein.  Left calf veins were not clearly 
identified, 
possibly also occluded. 
2.  No right DVT. 

LAST LABS BEFORE DISCHARGE 
===============================
___ 06:55AM BLOOD WBC-14.9* RBC-3.51* Hgb-11.5 Hct-36.8 
MCV-105* MCH-32.8* MCHC-31.3* RDW-13.8 RDWSD-53.1* Plt ___
___ 06:55AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-32* Creat-0.9 Na-144 
K-3.7 Cl-96 HCO3-37* AnGap-15
___ 06:55AM BLOOD Albumin-2.5* Calcium-8.0* Phos-3.2 
Mg-1.5*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ y/o F with PMHx CHF, Afib not on 
anticoagulation, severe advanced Alzheimer's dementia, 
osteoporosis, HTN, who presents from assisted living facility 
with R hip pain, found to have DVT left common femoral vein with 
volume overload. During a meeting with patient and her family, 
decision was made to transition care to comfort-directed 
measures only and to pursue hospice services on discharge. 

ACTIVE ISSUES 
=============
# CMO. The team had a family meeting on ___ and decision was 
made to transition care to CMO and pursue 24 hour hospice 
services on discharge. Family did not want to pursue active 
treatments such as Lasix, which would make her uncomfortable 
given incontinence or shots such as lovenox for treatment of 
DVT. Home medications metoprolol, donepezil and Memantine were 
continued for comfort. She was discharged to an ___ 
___ facility. 

OTHER HOSPITAL ISSUES 
=====================

# DVT. Deep vein thrombosis of the left common femoral vein 
extending into at least the popliteal vein diagnosed on 
ultrasound on admission. This was likely acquired in the setting 
of immobility, as the patient had been restricted to her 
wheelchair at her assisted living for greater than 1 month due 
to deconditioning. She was initially started on Lovenox for 
treatment but this was discontinued in the setting of transition 
to care to CMO as above. 

# Acute CHF. Patient was volume overloaded on presentation with 
pleural effusions. She was diuresed with IV Lasix. Home 
metoprolol was continued at a decreased dose. In the setting of 
transition to care to CMO, Lasix was discontinued. She was 
continued on metoprolol for comfort. She remained on room air 
without respiratory distress.  

# Afib. She presented in sinus rhythm, rate controlled on 
metoprolol. Metoprolol was continued at a decreased dose for 
comfort. 

# Hip pain. The right hip pain that she presented with was 
resolved by the time of admission. Pelvic xray was without 
fracture. She was treated with Tylenol scheduled for pain 
control. 

# Al___ Dementia. She was AOx1 at her baseline per family 
members. She was continued on Aricept/Namenda.  

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES 
===================

- ___ facility to continue writing orders for 
pain/anxiety/secretions and other symptoms. 
- Continued metoprolol succinate and Memantine and donepezil on 
discharge for comfort. Continuation of these medications can be 
further decided at inpatient hospice. 
- MOLST form: DNR/DNI, do not re-hospitalize 

# CODE: DNR/DNI, CMO 
# CONTACT: HCP ___ (daughter) ___ Primary, 
secondary ___ (son) ___
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO BID 
2. Torsemide 40 mg PO DAILY 
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
4. Donepezil 10 mg PO QHS 
5. raloxifene 60 mg oral DAILY 
6. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
7. Namenda XR (MEMAntine) 21 mg oral DAILY 
8. Ascorbic Acid ___ mg PO DAILY 
9. Calcium Carbonate 1500 mg PO DAILY 
10. Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY 
11. Fish Oil (Omega 3) 1000 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Donepezil 10 mg PO QHS 
2. Metoprolol Succinate XL 200 mg PO DAILY 
3. Namenda XR (MEMAntine) 21 mg oral DAILY 
4. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO TID 
5. Glycopyrrolate 0.1 mg IV Q6H:PRN excess secretions 
6. Hyoscyamine 0.125 mg SL QID:PRN excess secretions  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis  
--------------- 
Deep Vein Thrombosis  
 
Secondary Diagnosis  
------------------ 
Congestive heart failure 
Atrial fibrillation  
Constipation  
Malnutrition  
Hypertension  
Alzheimer's dementia  

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization. Briefly, you were hospitalized with right hip 
pain. We did Xrays of your hip which did not show any fractures. 
We also found a blood clot in your left leg and noticed that 
your heart wasn't pumping very efficiently. We talked with you 
and your family, who shared with us many of your wishes about 
being hospitalized and the type of care you would like to 
receive. We decided to focus on your comfort. Because of this, 
you are being discharged to ___ for hospice care.   

We wish you and your family the ___, 

Your ___ Treatment Team 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

answers.text: The patient is a female with a history of CHF, Afib not on anticoagulation, severe advanced Alzheimer's dementia, osteoporosis, and HTN. She presented to the hospital with sudden onset right hip pain and was found to have a DVT in her left leg. She was also diagnosed with acute CHF and atrial fibrillation. She was treated with diuresis and started on Lovenox for DVT treatment. During her hospitalization, a family meeting was held, and the decision was made to transition care to comfort-directed measures only and to pursue hospice services on discharge. She was discharged to an extended care facility with hospice care.

qas.question: (Text Summarization) Provide a brief summary of the history treatment plan for the patient?

answers.text: During a meeting with patient and her family,  decision was made to transition care to comfort-directed  measures only and to pursue hospice services on discharge.

qas.question: (Content extraction) Which sentences in the note describe the history treatment plan for the patient?
(Text Summarization) Provide a brief summary of the future treatment plan for the patient?

answers.text: We decided to focus on your comfort. Because of this,  you are being discharged to ___ for hospice care.
decision was made to transition care to comfort-directed  measures only and to pursue hospice services on discharge.
Family did not want to pursue active  treatments such as Lasix, which would make her uncomfortable  given incontinence or shots such as lovenox for treatment of  DVT.
